===Etymology===
From {{inh|en|enm|fox}}, from {{inh|en|ang|fox||fox}}, from {{inh|en|gmw-pro|*fuhs}}, from {{inh|en|gem-pro|*fuhsaz||fox}}, from {{inh|en|ine-pro|*pÃºá¸±sos||the tailed one}}, possibly from {{m|ine-pro|*puá¸±-||tail}}.

Cognate with {{cog|sco|fox||fox}}, {{cog|fy|foks||fox}}, Fering-Ã–Ã¶mrang {{cog|frr|foos}} and SÃ¶lring and Heligoland {{m|frr|fos}}, {{cog|nl|vos||fox}}, {{cog|nds|vos||fox}}, {{cog|de|Fuchs||fox}}, {{cog|is|fÃ³a||fox}}, {{cog|txb|pÃ¤kÄ||tail, chowrie}}, {{cog|ru|Ğ¿ÑƒÑ…||down, fluff}}, {{cog|sa|à¤ªà¥à¤šà¥à¤›|tr=pÃºccha}} (whence {{cog|trw|Ù¾ÙˆØ´|tr=pÅ«Å¡||fox}}, {{cog|hi|à¤ªà¥‚à¤‚à¤›|t=tail}}).

===Noun===
{{en-noun|+|foxen|pl2qual=nonstandard, dialectal}}

# A [[red fox]], small [[carnivore]] (''[[Vulpes vulpes]]''), related to dogs and wolves, with red or silver [[fur]] and a [[bushy]] [[tail]].
#: {{ux|en|The quick brown '''fox''' jumps over the lazy dog.}}
#* '''15<sup>th</sup> century''', ''{{w|The Fox (folk song)|The Fox}}'', {{nowrap|verse 1:}}
#*: The '''fox''' went out on a chase one night, / he prayed to the Moon to give him light, / for he had many a mile to go that night / before he reached the town-o, town-o, town-o. / He had many a mile to go that night / before he reached the town-o.
#* {{RQ:Jefferies Amateur Poacher|chapter=The First Gun|page=1|passage=They burned the old gun that used to stand in the dark corner up in the garret, close to the stuffed '''fox''' that always grinned so fiercely. Perhaps the reason why he seemed in such a ghastly rage was that he did not come by his death fairly. Otherwise his pelt would not have been so perfect. And why else was he put away up there out of sight?â€”and so magnificent a brush as he had too.}}
# Any of numerous [[species]] of small [[wild]] [[canid]]s resembling the red fox. In the [[taxonomy]] they form the tribe [[Vulpini]] within the family [[Canidae]], consisting of nine [[genera]] (see the [[w:Fox|Wikipedia article on the fox]]).
# The [[fur]] of a fox.
# A [[fox terrier]].
# The {{vern|gemmeous dragonet}}, a [[fish]], {{taxlink|Callionymus lyra|species|ver=160924}}, so called from its yellow color.
# A [[cunning]] person.
# {{lb|en|slang|metaphor}} A physically attractive man or woman.
#* '''1993''', {{w|Laura Antoniou}}, ''{{w|The Marketplace series|The Marketplace}}'', p.90:
#*: And Jerry was cute, you know, I liked him, but Frank was a total '''fox'''. And he was rougher than Jerry, you know, not so cultured.
#* {{quote-book|en|year=2012|author=Adele Parks|title=Still Thinking of You|passage=It wasn't just that Jayne was a '''fox''' â€“ although, fuck, was she ever a fox. That arse, those tits, those lips. They could have a really good time together.}}
# {{lb|en|nautical}} A small strand of [[rope]] made by twisting several rope-yarns together. Used for [[seizing]]s, [[mat]]s, [[sennit]]s, and [[gasket]]s.
# {{lb|en|mechanics}} A [[wedge]] driven into the split end of a [[bolt]] to tighten it.
# A [[hidden]] [[radio]] [[transmitter]], finding which is the goal of [[radiosport]].
#* '''2006''', H. Ward Silver, ''The ARRL Ham Radio License Manual''
#*: Locating a hidden transmitter (the '''fox''') has been a popular ham activity for many years.
# {{lb|en|cartomancy}} The fourteenth [[Lenormand]] card.
# {{lb|en|obsolete}} A [[sword]]; so called from the stamp of a fox on the blade, or perhaps of a wolf taken for a fox.
#* {{RQ:Shakespeare Henry 5|act=IV|scene=iv|passage=Thou diest on point of '''fox'''.}}

===Verb===
{{en-verb}}

# {{lb|en|transitive}} To [[trick]], [[fool]] or [[outwit]] (someone) by [[cunning]] or [[ingenuity]].
# {{lb|en|transitive}} To [[confuse]] or [[baffle]] (someone).
#: ''This crossword puzzle has completely '''foxed''' me.''
# {{lb|en|intransitive}} To act [[slyly]] or [[craftily]].
# {{lb|en|intransitive}} To [[discolour]] paper. Fox marks are spots on paper caused by [[humidity]]. (See {{m|en|foxing}}.)
#: ''The pages of the book show distinct '''foxing'''.''
# {{lb|en|transitive}} To make sour, as beer, by causing it to ferment.
# {{lb|en|intransitive}} To turn [[sour]]; said of [[beer]], etc., when it sours in [[ferment]]ing.
# {{lb|en|transitive}} To [[intoxicate]]; to stupefy with drink.
#* {{RQ:Pepys Diary|II|29 September 1661}}
#*: I drank {{...}} so much wine that I was almost '''foxed'''.
# {{lb|en|transitive}} To repair (boots) with new front upper leather, or to piece the upper fronts of.
